results.name: a(n) is the number of iterations needed to reach a power of 2 starting at n and using the map k -> k + k/p, where p is the largest prime factor of k.
comment: Let f(n) = A000265(n) be the odd part of n. Let p be the largest prime factor of k, and say k = p * m. Suppose that k is not a power of 2, i.e., p > 2, then f(k) = p * f(m). The iteration is k -> k + k/p = p*m + m = (p+1) * m. So, p * f(m) -> f(p+1) * f(m). Since for p > 2, f(p+1) < p, the odd part in each each iteration decreases, until it becomes 1, i.e., until we reach a power of 2. - _Amiram Eldar_, Feb 19 2020
Any odd prime factor of k can be used at any step of the iteration, and the result will be same. Thus, like A329697, this is also fully additive sequence. - _Antti Karttunen_, Apr 29 2020
If and only if a(n) is equal to A005087(n), then sigma(2n) - sigma(n) is a power of 2. (See A336923, A046528). - _Antti Karttunen_, Mar 16 2021
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..65537
formula: This is a completely additive sequence: a(2) = 0, a(p) = 1+a(p+1) for odd primes p, a(m*n) = a(m)+a(n), if m,n > 1.
If A209229(n) == 1, a(n) = 0, otherwise a(n) = 1 + a(n+A052126(n)), or equally, 1 + a(n+(n/A078701(n))).
example: The trajectory of 15 is [15,18,24,32], taking 3 iterations to reach 32. So, a(15) = 3.
mathematica: a[n_] := -1 + Length @ NestWhileList[# + #/FactorInteger[#][[-1, 1]] &, n, # / 2^IntegerExponent[#, 2] != 1 &]; Array[a, 100] (* _Amiram Eldar_, Jan 16 2020 *)
program: (MAGMA) f:=func<n|n+n div p where p is Max(PrimeDivisors(n))>; g:=func<n| n eq 1 or Max(PrimeDivisors(n)) eq 2>; a:=[]; for n in [1..1000] do k:=n; s:=0; while not g(k) do  s:=s+1; k:=f(k); end while; Append(~a,s); end for; a; // _Marius A. Burtea_, Jan 19 2020
(PARI) A331410(n) = { my(k=0); while(bitand(n,n-1), k++; my(f=factor(n)[, 1]); n += (n/f[2-(n%2)])); (k); }; \\ _Antti Karttunen_, Apr 29 2020
xref: Cf. A000265, A005087, A006530 (greatest prime factor), A052126, A078701, A087436, A329662 (positions of records and the first occurrences of each n), A334097, A334098, A334108, A334861, A336467, A336921, A336922, A336923 (A046528).
Cf. array A335430, and its rows A335431, A335882, and also A335874.
Cf. also A329697 (analogous sequence when using the map k -> k - k/p), A335878.
Cf. also A330437, A335884, A335885, A336362, A336363 for other similar iterations.
